body: Upon closer inspection of the Alamofire source code, it seems that `responseSerializerDidComplete()` is called async on the underlying queue, so it does not happen immediately with `appendResponseSerializer()` Then `processNextResponseSerializer()` here merely finds the next response serializer by index and then calls it async without trying to remove it. If `processNextResponseSerializer()` is called multiple times in quick succession due to internal bugs with Apple's framework, then it would seem possible for `serializationQueue.async { responseSerializer() }` to be invoked multiple times, leading to `responseSerializerDidComplete()` to be called multiple times, which eventually calls the final completion handler multiple times. This is only my speculation, could be totally off.

Thanks for the report! I can take a look at that logic, as it could likely benefit from being more atomic anyway, but looking at your callstack, it's a bit odd. There shouldn't be anything that can go from `DataRequest._response` to `DownloadRequest.downladTask` to `DataRequest.dataTask`. Do you have any more traces I can see? (No need for screen shots, you can copy / paste the content.)

Upon further digging in the Xcode organizer, I found 3 crashes of this kind over the span of maybe a few months. The most recent one would be the 4th one, not sure why Xcode organizer can't include it. It is overall quite rare. They however all have the same weird stack trace: Assume the stack trace is reliable, one common pattern I find for all reports is that they all come from "closure #2 in closure #2 in closure #3 in closure #1 in DataRequest._response", which seems to be the error case after serializing a response.
Would you mind pasting some crash log content?

> Would you mind pasting some crash log content?

Crash log content as in the crash log file? What specific information are you looking for?

> > Would you mind pasting some crash log content?
> 
> Crash log content as in the crash log file? What specific information are you looking for?

Yeah, the info so far doesnâ€™t give me any clue. More details, like the exception type might help.

I have seen similar crashes in my application. Happy to attach crash logs if needed.

Thanks @FlickerSoul, that's pretty definitive. Though you should be careful when posting raw backtraces, you had a full access token and refresh token in there.

I'll see if I can get all my Alamofire changes and fixes in later this week and over the weekend.
Thank you so much! Didn't notice I had tokens there and I just deleted the comment. :))

@jshier I tried to look into Alamofire source code and noticed this potential misuse: When `appendResponseSerializer(_:)` is called, it checks for a flag `mutableState.responseSerializerProcessingFinished`, if true, it immediately kick starts the `processNextResponseSerializer` chain. The issue is that `mutableState.responseSerializerProcessingFinished` is only set to true once upon request completion and never set back to false, so it does not guard against the case where once a request finishes, client reuses it and appends more response serializers in quick succession. This can potentially trigger `processNextResponseSerializer` more than once at a time, which breaks its serial execution design, causing the 1st serializer to fire twice. Of course, this may not be the actual reason for the crashes at all, but it shows potential problems with `processNextResponseSerializer` usage. The whole request retry logic is quite complex and I tried to wrap my head around it but didn't get very far. I am not sure if there could be any potential concurrency issue there. Of course, if the client implements the request retrier wrong and invokes completion multiple times, it will lead to quite a disaster since `responseSerializerDidComplete(completion:)` will be invoked multiple times. Maybe it could use a safety check too.

Yes, that behavior is intentional, to support exactly the use case you state: the user tried to append response serializers after processing had already completed. Rather than fail them, we process them immediately. 

This particular crash is caused by the single response serializer of a `DataTask` being called more than once and attempting to resume the continuation both times. There appears to be some path that allows that to happen. I likely just need to tighten up the atomic behavior of the serializer processing, as there's probably some time outside the lock that allows a codepath to execute twice.

A question for @LeoTheCatMeow and @FlickerSoul, are you using multiple response serializers at all, or just one `.serializing...` method that creates the `DataTask` that you can `await`?

I think I only use a single `.serializing`. The specific structure is like the following

```
someRequest
  .response
  .serializingResponse(using: CustomSerializer)
```

I do use this with interceptors like authentication interceptor or retry interceptor.

@FlickerSoul Could you post your backtrace again? Just make sure to remove any private data, and I only need the crashing thread with Alamofire in it.

I can't otherwise seem to replicate the crash at all, so I'm going to have to do a speculative fix for the next release.
